headline: Italian Baked Eggplant with Parmesan (Parmigiana di Melanzane)
description: This authentic recipe for eggplant parmigiana with baked eggplant, tomato sauce, and Parmesan is one of the most popular Italian dishes.

video.description: Watch how to make real Italian baked eggplant with Parmesan.
video.name: Italian Baked Eggplant with Parmesan (Parmigiana di melanzane)

name: Italian Baked Eggplant with Parmesan (Parmigiana di Melanzane)
recipeIngredient: 3 pounds large eggplants, sliced lengthwise into 1/4-inch slices
2 tablespoons coarse salt, or as needed
1.5 (16 ounce) packages fresh mozzarella cheese, sliced

recipeInstructions.text: Place a single layer of eggplant slices in a colander sitting on a plate and sprinkle with coarse salt. Cover with a second layer and sprinkle with salt. Repeat with remaining eggplant. Place a plate on top and add a weight to put pressure on the eggplant slices. Let stand at room temperature for about 1 hour.
Rinse eggplant slices under running cold water to wash off all the salt. Pat dry on all sides with paper towels.

Heat oil in a deep skillet over medium-high heat. Dredge eggplant slices in flour on both sides and add to the hot oil, working in batches. Deep fry eggplant until golden, 2 to 3 minutes per side. Drain on paper towels.

Heat olive oil in a large pot over medium heat; cook garlic and onion until soft and translucent, about 5 minutes. Add tomato puree, 4 basil leaves, and salt. Cook, stirring often, until sauce starts to thicken, about 20 minutes. Remove sauce from heat. Discard garlic and stir in remaining 4 leaves basil.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Spread a layer of tomato sauce over the bottom of a baking dish. Cover with a single layer of eggplant slices. Top with more sauce, mozzarella slices, and Parmesan cheese. Continue making layers, a total of 3 to 5, finishing with tomato sauce and grated Parmesan cheese.
Bake in the preheated oven until heated through and bubbling, 30 to 40 minutes. Remove from oven and let stand for 20 minutes before serving.

review.reviewBody:
Was good but it didn't go over like other recipes I've gotten here. Husband liked that thought, he had the left overs.
Won't stop me from e using allrecipes thought love them.

My first try was a dud, because of what happened in the frying phase. It took about 6 batches to get the slices all fried. I did not change the cooking oil between batches. (Maybe that was my mistake.) By the later batches, the oil was full of black, burned flour that had fallen off while frying the earlier batches, and apparently the last batches soaked up a lot of this soot. So the eggplants tasted more like burned toast than like eggplants. I'm considering, next time, (a) oil-coating and baking the eggplants as some commenters have suggested, or (b) frying the eggplants per the recipe but without the flour coating, or (c) breading and deep-frying them all at once in a deep fryer (like they cook fries at McDonald's) so the burnt flour would not have a chance to pollute the later batches. Anybody got predictions about how (b) and (c) might turn out, to spare me some trial-and-error? Thanks in advance.

We liked it - my husband would have liked the eggplant crispy with a breading, but said that it tasted good. I baked them in the oven with olive oil like some of them said they had done to cut down the grease.
I used Shredded skim mozzarella and layered sliced hard boil eggs in between layers as suggested by an authentic Italian lady as a tradition for Easter. It was amazingly delicious.
My first time eating eggplant. I have to say that I will be making this again. We loved it!
Such a great recipe. Made but used marinara sauce and added a layer of sautéed mushrooms to th layer,
This recipe came out delish. Shared with a Nieghbor and guess what she went out bought all ingredients and asked if I would make more guess what I am thank you.

I brushed the eggplant with olive oil, sprinkled some Italian seasoning on both sides, and baked it for 30 mins (rather than frying it) on parchment paper to save some calories. Then followed the rest of the recipe--it's a winner!
This would be 5 stars if the eggplant was dredged in flour (or corn starch), dipped in egg, then coated in bread crumbs before pan frying.

This recipe was so delicious and surprisingly easy to make. I didn’t change a thing except I only had dried basil which I used by eye balling. It tasted better than that famous Italian restaurant chain! My meat lover husband said this is a keeper!
Was looking for an eggplant recipe that did not usage egg whites and discovered this one. Excellent! loved using slices of cheese instead of shredded too.
No changes and WILL make again.
Instead of frying, I baked it in a 350 oven for about half an hour. I lightly brushed it with EVOO before baking. Delicious!
fantastic recipe! will make again often

DELICIOUS. Everyone loved it and the only change I made was to take the drained eggplant, brush it on both sides with olive oil, and bake it in a 350 degree oven for about 30 minutes instead of frying it. This dish takes time to make but it is amazing.

item.name: Italian Baked Eggplant with Parmesan (Parmigiana di Melanzane)
